I think if we add an avatar menu, it would probably make the most sense to use it primarily for user status management, similarly to other apps:

Screen-Shot-2022-07-05-at-10.48.39-AM.png
Screen-Shot-2022-07-05-at-10.49.03-AM.png

So I could see it having:

  • Your presence indicator (informational only)
  • Set status (for setting emoji statuses)
  • Go invisible (cf. Replace "Unavailable" status with "Invisible" mode #21178)
  • Personal settings
  • (maybe) Manage notifications (Personal settings > Notifications)
  • Log out

But I think we'd want to keep copies of Personal settings and Log out in the gear menu, so the gear menu itself wouldn't actually change.

Note that this is somewhat different from the direction in the in-progress PR we have from last year (navbar: Replace gear menu with avatar and show status icon. #17276), which was discussed in https://chat.zulip.org/#narrow/stream/3-backend/topic/status-expire/near/1114757.
What do folks think? If folks like the proposal, I could file an issue, though I don't think it would be an urgent one.

I think that sort of vision, where the gear menu remains the main place to do things, and the avatar menu is just for status and perhaps 1-2 duplicates of things from the gear menu, is potentially a solution to the problem of "Making two menus just means users have to click both to find things."

I'm not sure whether it's better than what we have today or just changing the icon for the gear menu to be your avatar.

@Taiki Choda We should not rename any of the existing options in this redesign pass. So the wording in the PR won't quite match the wording in the design spec, which is fine. (For example, if we decide to rename private messages to direct messages, that would be a separate project.)
Similarly, when adding an option from the user card to the new user menu, we should use the current option naming.
Sorry if this wasn't clearly indicated on the issue!

Just to talk a bit about why this is important: Renaming a feature is a complex project in itself, since it requires coordinated changes across the UI, documentation, etc., and generally we want to do that sort of thing as a single independent project, so we can check our work on it and make sure we made the change correctly and completely.

One of the most important parts of creating work that can be merged into a large project like Zulip is figuring out a scope for a change such that one can integrate chunk having verified that each one has no regressions.
